posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91445515
>how does that help if I'm not home?
thats why theres a usb or network port, dummy

your average UPS is only there to prevent an instant poweroff. they are designed specifically to be configured such that when theres a power outtage, they tell your equipment to safely power down. the 7 minutes of runtime is to keep it running over intermittant, 1-2 minute brownouts, and the other few minutes are for VM migration, quick snapshot jobs, timeout timers, etc.

if you want a UPS witu several hoyrs of runtime, you get a stacking UPS and like four external battery modules, and it costs you 5-6* the price
also if your UPS only runs your equipment for 7 minutes it might be undersized. mine is actually pretty small and it runs my entire rack for 15 minutes. that's nearly 500 watts!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91445652
for example, when my UPS detects a low voltage input, it tells proxmox to to a live snapshot of all containers and VMs and theb it waits until it's at 50% capacity (which lasts about three to five minutes, enough to cover a brownout). once it's at 50% capacity, it's clear it's gonna be a long blackout, so it tells proxmox to softly shut down all containers and VMs, and then shut itself down too. it then tells the router to do the same, and then it shuts off the power for the switch and turns itself off until it detects normal voltage inputs again, and which time it turns the switches back on and tells all the servers to wake-on-lan

all without me needing to lift a finger, and proxmox send me an email alert too. if yiu run windows you could tell it to hybernate and it writes it's current state to disk so everything is exactly how you left it when powet returns

also picrel is my UPS (there is actually two, one at the back of the rack). 960w 1600va and runs the whole rack (about 500w) for 10-15 minutes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91446179
The antenna(faraday cage) is induced to retransmit the outside signal at exactly inverse phase. So it cancels out with the outside signal. In other words, the outside EMP goes right through the box like it's not even there, but the box itself starts radiating an inverse signal that interferes with the outside signal, and inside the box they're the same strength.
If you think about it like just electric charge it makes sense, when the signal is negative, the box becomes positive;y charged to match it and vice versa.

>>91421327
How much content is there for it? 5.1 has been around since the 1970s yet virtually all music is still mixed in stereo. Assuming what you're listening to has the metadata to support it, it's still just essentially making a two channel binaural recording when played through IEMs which isn't customized to the individual and 3D sound as if you were truly in the room is not possible regardless of the marketing wank.

Forget the amount of channels, the future of immersive sound will utilize head tracking and individualized head-related transfer functions. There are primitive attempts at this that use photos of the pinna to try to calculate it but it's still early days and it can't exactly account for ear canal shape so who knows how close it can get. Anyway this topic is a dead horse at this point and I don't want this thread devolve into "soundstage" shit flinging.

US version has normal power output (1.0V RMS).

If you use it on Android power gets cut in half again (0.25V RMS). That happens ONLY on Android, on Windows you still get 0.5V.

posts.com: For that idiot who was saying inverted polarity is minimum phase and that having no excess group delay means the system is minimum phase.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91425221
Not the anon you were arguing with, but Rene is actually contradicting himself in the video. Excess phase doesn't strictly mean a system is not minimum phase. The definition of minimum phase system is that the system and its inverse are causal and stable - and he does mention it in the video. Transfer function required to undo flipped polarity is causal and stable. Which he also does mention in the video and he doesn't consider polarity flip a problem https://youtube.com/watch?v=iBPTvMgRBe0&t=1h18m30s. Yet he calls polarity flip not minimum phase in his overview. A contradiction. But none of this really matters due to the fact that a system doesn't need to be minimum phase to have no phase and magnitude distortions, it just needs to be linear phase(constant delay), sound traveling from the driver to the eardrum is already not minimum phase.

>>91425546
I agree that the semantics of it are besides the point and that inverted polarity can be viewed as a special case since its inverse is causal and stable when the transducer is viewed as a system. These topics are defined rather unclearly and there is no clear-cut answer in the textbooks. Simply saying that there is high excess phase and that the phase response does not follow the predicted minimum phase response per the Hilbert transform would be more technically correct.

posts.com:
>>91433643
Imagine climbing a tree and shitting down from there. The height, in this case, is analogous to the voltage. (+) is the top where you are, (-) is the ground.
The amount of shit falling on the ground per second is analogous to amperage.
Branches of all kinds, wind, etc. is analogous to resistance.

Also, for a complete analogy you have to introduce nuances (reading more will only confuse you, but when you get the hang of it, it will complete the picture).
You have to shit (according to the conditions) in a continuous flow, so the higher you go, the more you shit.
The fewer obstacles, branches, or you shit in a vacuum, the faster it will reach the ground, the more you have to shit for the flow to be continuous. If there comes a point where your ass can't shit as much as it should, you get a drop. Your ass can burn out, you need a fuse.

https://www.techpowerup.com/review/hogwarts-legacy-benchmark-test-performance-analysis/7.html

Just like in most other recent releases, shader compiling and stuttering is a problem in Hogwarts Legacy. Right on startup, before the main menu, the game presents you a "compiling shaders" screen that lasts for three to five minutes. Unfortunately the shaders that get compiled at this time are only the most essential ones. As you progress through the game you'll encounter serious drops in framerate (to unplayable levels) for about 30 seconds. Just stop and wait for the shader compiler to finish—this breaks the immersion of course and I wonder if this can't be solved more elegantly. I investigated a bit further and the game is compiling shaders in the background even during normal stutter-free gameplay, too, without affecting the game much. We've seen such problems in many games recently and I keep hearing how these will get fixed in the "day one" patch, "soon" after launch, maybe with the next big patch, or with the next DLC. For nearly all games these issues never get fixed, and there's never any noteworthy performance improvements, so /doubt. My recommendation is to just live with it, stop playing for a few seconds when you get hit by the stutter, take a short break, and resume when things are smooth again. Just to clarify, for 98% of my play time in the first few hours there was no stutter and no frame drop issues, everything was super smooth.

>>91446019
Think of it as simulating mirrors instead of simulating light. It’s manipulating the viewer in to thinking, a floor for instance, is so reflective and reactive in real time. but only on certain things like big polished floors or puddles of water or large panes of glass.

It renders in reverse the image being reflected and at times is super impressive. Like when it’s specifically used on something like a weapons scope. But it doesn’t show up on smaller scale objects like side mirrors on a car parked in front of you, or the leaves of a wet bush or the reflection on a cathode tv.

It’s fun, but not worth losing 20-30fps on average.

>>91445788
>>91445972

Is Vulkan's raytracing even suitable for production renderers? It's not like they don't support Vulkan, it's more like Vulkan itself isn't ready for that type of application. For Blender specifically everything has already been designed to work for CUDA and OptiX for years, so all the other vendors have to keep their implementations similar to those in order to not have to maintain whole separate branches of the engine and can reuse as much as possible.

OpenCL is dead, they've been trying to get it to work for over a decade and it was so shit that the blender foundation dropped support for it entirely. If that didn't happen, AMD would still be sitting on they asses instead of finally implementing HIP support. By the way, SYCL is also a Khronos thing and Intel chose that for their implementation. There is a whole presentation about it here:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YDVZIv25T7U

>>91437473
terrible advice. no companies use "Arch" -- there are only really three variants of Linux that MOST companies use:


1) RHEL (you can earn chops using AlmaLinux or Rocky Linux here, CentOS is effectively dead)
2) Ubuntu (LTS only, don't bother with Debian because there is no "company" to back it up)
3) SUSE (being a FAR distant third, don't even bother if you are in the US, stick to RHEL and Ubuntu

Get comfortable with the command line. Deploy a virtual server running one of the above. Go to /hsg/ and do all the things.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91438387
I’m only in helpdesk, have a two-year IT degree, so take my advice with a grain of salt.

My experience so far has been that almost everyone that works on the Infrastructure side of IT is too stupid to be a developer. Therefore, there’s a lot of competition and waiting time to move up.

I’ve found 80% of people in helpdesk fall into two categories: those that aren’t competent to leave helpdesk and those that would be competent sysadmins but ended up in helpdesk because of the job market. Only about 20% of people in helpdesk/desktop support are exactly where they should be at their skill level, but will eventually be able to grow into a sysadmin role.

I’ve been using Linux since 2007 and was the sharpest in my class. I felt that my first two helpdesk jobs were a serious waste of my capabilities, so I quit both of them. Now I’m on my third helpdesk job, looking flakey, so I have to stay at this job for at least a year. So here I am, telling people to clear their browser history and restart their computer all week.

Unless you get lucky, you’re gonna have to do your time in the helpdesk. Spend a year or two in your job, acquire certs, hopefully you can move up.

Or there’s dev. If you’re smart enough to learn how to be a dev in your spare time, go for it. If you’re intellectually capable of being a dev, it will be a lot more satisfying than working in infrastructure.

Another thing about staying in the infrastructure side of things is the constant demoralization. You’ll come on 4chan and the devs are making 1.5 times more than you for more enjoyable work. You’ll go on ITcareerquestions and people will be bragging about how they’re making 6 figures. You’ll go onto LinkedIn and see people moving up faster than you because they were in the right place at the right time.

>>91438387
Also though, if you do stay on the Infrastructure side of things, you should begin looking for better pay.

Where I live, entry level helpdesk was paying $22/hour in 2017. From my perspective, that means entry level should be paying $27/hour now. They’re not, but only because every year there’s a new batch of students willing to work for pennies, and we can always import more. You’re only willing to accept $40k because you’re young. You could make $25/hour delivering pizza.

I actually was making $24/hour delivering pizza before I got my degree. I told them that at the interview, and told them I’m not willing to work for less. They gave it to me. Turns out, I was making more than many of my younger coworkers that didn’t have enough life experience to know how much they’re getting screwed.

Don’t get too comfy until you’re making an adequate salary. Keep active on LinkedIn, you should get at least one recruiter per week contacting you about helpdesk jobs. Keep your ears open for salary increases.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your tech skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

https://github.com/gradio-app/gradio/issues/2470
leszekhanusz commented on Oct 16, 2022 • 
Describe the bug
The URLs currently produced when using the share option are in the form https://12345.gradio.app

The numbers at the start are way too easy to guess, a malicious actor can easily try every combination of numbers to find a specific application and could allow remote code execution depending on the application.

Possible solution: instead of using only 5 numbers with low entropy (10^5 = 100000), use something like 15 characters in the range [0-9][a-z][A-Z] (base 62) with (26+26+10)^15 = 7,689097049×1026 possibilities which will generate URLs looking like this: https://vteiTSJw4V0GOL5.gradio.app

Note: not reporting this issue as a security issue as this is already a public issue

Is there an existing issue for this?
 I have searched the existing issues

Took me way too long to realise that a good mix is based and good sound selection. You won't believe how many kicks I had that sound interesting but are fucked up because either they are too long, transients peaks, weird phase, useless frequencies.
I'm even considering deleting everything I won't use at the end of this year. Kinda retarded to have 500 kicks if you use only 50 of them on a regular basis.

>>91409522
I’ll provide some of my own personal enlightenment regarding this… obviously kicks are important, and the idea is ‘let me narrow down my kick samples to the more optimal versions so I’m not sifting through 500 samples”. But the reality is there is really only a finite number of kick styles people try to emulate when they make “mega kick sample packs” and 95% of them are emulating drum machines of the era where a specific genre debuted. Get the original kick samples from a 909, 808, 707, kawai r, Roland r series, Yamaha rx series, DMX, and linndrum; then you will have all of the types of kicks the sample-pack makers start from. Imo sculpting these kicks to fit into your mix will be a lot easier than searching through someone else’s pre-processed versions of them in hopes they were processed in a way to fit in your mix.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91413718
Making drum sounds doesn't necessarily mean using exclusively synthesis.
Layering samples and synths as needed is the standard for creating sounds.
You can layer real-world recorded snares with synthesized layers (it's common to have a recorded snare for the noise and a synth for the body), or layering foley samples to give them a slightly more interesting flavor can give you some pretty good results.
A big advantage is that you can make sure that every layer is tuned to the right note/s that make sense in the context of the track, without having to re-pitch a complete sample and changing its character.

And sure, some of the one-shots available online can sound much better than the best ones I can make, but so do the samples and presets (and MIDIs lol) for basses, leads, FX, pads, etc.
I make my own drums for the same reasons I make my own version of everything else. The added control and the fact that they're mine and sound like me.
Everyone has a threshold for what matters that they make it themselves and what doesn't. For me (because of how I approach music and the type of music I make itself) drums completely clear that threshold, but everyone is different and as much as we shitpost about sampling being cheating, it's perfectly valid to use samples if you care about the end result more than whatever makes someone want to go DIY.

TL;DR: There are advantages and disadvantages to every approach. Choose what's right for you.

>>91413678
I think it really does come down to what your are personally trying to achieve. If you have no intention of being faithful to a genre, there’s no reason to uphold some drum samples that are historically attached to a genre. But at the same time, knowing the drum machines that were used for specific genres does give you the ability to ‘tip you hat” to your influences in an authentic way. Plus there are electronic music genres that are defined specifically by the use of sampled drums vs synthesized drums (eg jungle vs dnb, breakbeat vs electro)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91431019
>should pan
No

>could pan
Yes, if you want to give more width to your mix, you can pan anything (apart from the kick, the bass and the main vocal, generally), just experiment with what you like and hear the results

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91431019
It's easy to understand - double basically any instrument you want (especially do this with vocals IMO), and pan them both 25% left and 25% right on separate mixer tracks, and you will almost immediately notice how much more vibrant your mix is.

>but can't you just increase the stereo width on one track

You can, but you're not going to have the full harmonizing effect because stereo width generally doesn't increase with volume, so you are widening the sound on a single channel, but it's just not as wide as the same instrument double panned l/r on 2 channels. You can do it on even more channels too.

>I'm worried about the volume being crazy

Worry about volume last, you can always turn your mix to mono to figure out your volume levels when you're done making it nice and fun.

>should I pan?

Maybe, maybe not, you have to trust your ears. Sometimes the effect will sound good, sometimes it will sound bad.

>download torrent
>plop into movies directory
>jellyfin automatically identifies it
>pulls down all the rating/genre/cast/trailer/etc stuff you'd see on netflix
>magically shows up in parents, kids, wife's, living room TV's client

so instead of netflix curating a library of videos and everyone downloading the netflix app, you curate a library of videos and everyone downloads a jellyfin/plex app. might take a weekend to set up but really seamless experience once you do. tons of step-by-step youtube videos available

You will never be a real display server. You have no hardware cursors, you have no xrandr, you have no setxkbmap. You are a toy project twisted by Red Hat and GNOME into a crude mockery of X11’s perfection.

All the “validation” you get is two-faced and half-hearted. Behind your back people mock you. Your developers are disgusted and ashamed of you, your “users” laugh at your lack of features behind closed doors.

Linux users are utterly repulsed by you. Thousands of years of evolution have allowed them to sniff out defective software with incredible efficiency. Even Wayland sessions that “work” look uncanny and unnatural to a seasoned sysadmin. Your bizarre render loop is a dead giveaway. And even if you manage to get a drunk Arch user home with you, he’ll turn tail and bolt the second he gets a whiff of your high latency due to forced VSync.

You will never be happy. You wrench out a fake smile every single morning and tell yourself it’s going to be ok, but deep inside you feel the technical debt creeping up like a weed, ready to crush you under the unbearable weight.

Eventually it’ll be too much to bear - you’ll log into the GitLab instance, select the project, press Delete, and plunge it into the cold abyss. Your users will find the deletion notice, heartbroken but relieved that they no longer have to live with the unbearable shame and disappointment. They’ll remember you as the biggest failure of open source development, and every passerby for the rest of eternity will know a badly run project has failed there. Your code will decay and go to historical archives, and all that will remain of your legacy is a codebase that is unmistakably poorly written.

This is your fate. This is what you chose. There is no turning back.

I bought a Thinkpad X1 Tablet Gen2 on a whim for $80 fully preparing myself to get ripped off but turns out I wasn't. All is fine. Yes, the BIOS is not locked. I read online people hate it though.

Instead of using it as a tablet or with it's flimsy keyboard I put it on a stand which has USB stuff integrated on my desk and combined it with a proper mech keyboard. the 2160x1440 12" 3:2 screen with over 200 PPI gives me eyegasms when writing. Running a very lightweight, customized Linux on it. I upgraded it's drive to 1 TB now. The CPU is more than good enough for browsing and running emacs OS.

It only sips power, is completely quiet and looks really cute. I stream slower (as in not reflex dependant) videogames from my desktop to it via ffmpeg. I actually fucking love this thing as a non-mobile small computer. Best risky buy in a long time.

I now actually want a small thinkpad with massive battery for on the go. Pity the older models all have such terrible screens compared to this one.

>>91441320
Godot is a fly trap. It attracts autists who were too dumb to understand programming on their own and traps them with an "easy" proprietary language that has way worse documentation and tutorials than established languages. C# and everything are second to this meme scripting language for some reason, despite
Godot's node system teaches noobs to make a bunch of different objects and handlers and then use a giant ass event bus singleton to manage them. Godot's very nature teaches noobs terrible programming habits.
Godot is honestly best suited for experienced developers, but the retarded insistence on GDScript being king keeps potential experts in other languages from making the jump.
There's a reason why Godot has been out since 2014 (actually development started in 2007) and the only notable games to its name are Cruelty Squad and Dome Keeper (and even DK is unfinished). There's the Sonic Colors port but that only partially used Godot. So far, Godot's only real use is to make shitty looking desktop apps. Every other Godot "developer" out there just puts out shitty flash game rip offs for game jams.
And no, Godot is not guaranteed to succeed because Blender succeeded. Blender had the functionality down for the most part, it was just that it wasn't very user friendly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91397162
A couple of things I would say:
Who communicates with their doctor thru email? That's not a secure platform and from my experience in dealing with medical records data, most Dr offices are avoiding using email due to HIPAA regulations and security risks. Only talk to a medical office over the phone or in person, even if they offer communication over email. Same goes for text, nothing over SMS.
My opinion on username for personal email address, is the same system I've always recommended in this thread and others on /g/, take your initials and convert to hexadecimal. In most cases you'll have a unique 6 character alphanumeric name that no one else has already taken (unless it's Gmail which you shouldn't use to begin with).
The reason why I'm saying don't use PII in email is because even if it's just for "normie" stuff, it don't matter. You don't have control over the email once it leaves your inbox, and if someone you're communicating with gets hacked or beached, then it's out in the open that is your email much easier because it will have your full name as the handle (which is just metadata not even the data itself), and bonus retard points for people who put their birthday in the handle. Seriously, with just those data points, name and birthday, someone could easily do harm to you and even find your SSN matched to that on the dark web and start opening credit in your name. I've seen this happen before.
So in short, just don't use PII in your email or anything else online, and don't even include a name field for outgoing email.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91391700
>What risks should I be concerned with, if any?
From what I gathered respective to DIY web hosting, you'll need a good firewall that intercepts illegitimate requests to your server (whitelist instead of blacklist, block everything that you don't explicitly want) and you need a well closed down system to run your server on. Set it up in a way that even if someone got on the server, they can't do anything. Containerize, MAC, etc. Read this article, it goes into bad and good practices:

https://www.ranum.com/security/computer_security/editorials/dumb/

>If you look at major internet applications you'll find that there are a number that consistently have problems with security vulnerabilities. There are also a handful, like PostFix, Qmail, etc, that were engineered to be compartmented against themselves, with modularized permissions and processing, and - not surprisingly - they have histories of amazingly few bugs. The same logic applies to "penetration testing." There are networks that I know of which have been "penetration tested" any number of times and are continually getting hacked to pieces. That's because their design (or their security practices) are so fundamentally flawed that no amount of turd polish is going to keep the hackers out. It just keeps managers and auditors off of the network administrator's backs. I know other networks that it is, literally, pointless to "penetration test" because they were designed from the ground up to be permeable only in certain directions and only to certain traffic destined to carefully configured servers running carefully secured software. Running a "penetration test" for Apache bugs is completely pointless against a server that is running a custom piece of C code that is running in a locked-down portion of an embedded system. So, "Penetrate and Patch" is pointless either because you know you're going to find an endless litany of bugs, or because you know you're not going to find anything comprehensible.

>>91394642
Make a threat model and lay out exactly who is going to harm you and how they can do this. Only when you understand the problem can you implement a solution. Just randomly using "le privacy" services won't help you.

The best privacy you can have is buying some used laptop second hand, put a Tails DVD into it and use some public Wifi. It will be near impossible to find out who you are, as no one will give a shit as long as you are not some hardcore criminal.

If you want a central question to build your privacy around, then ask yourself: what personally identifiable information does X contain? Apply this to all steps on the way, from your internet provider, your router, your IP, your browser, your OS, your hardware, what identification do each of these provide inside the communication chain? IMEI, IMSI, serial numbers, firmware versions, etc. - they all create a fingerprint. If you want real privacy, you'll have to diffuse these and that is an ass full of effort, not worth it for everyday 4chan browsing.

>>91417397
I'd recommend Mint for beginners. It's super Windows like and has GUI software manager. Your first steps into Linux CLI (command line interface) will be "sudo apt-get update" and "sudo apt-get upgrade", this checks for updates and installs them respectively. Search for software with "sudo apt search XYZ" and install it with "sudo apt-get install XYZ". Congratulations, you now "know Linux". To run programs from the CLI, simply input their name, i.e. "firefox" > starts firefox. "sudo reboot" reboots your machine. Ctrl + C cancels a process that is running inside that terminal window. "ping xyz.com" pings that website, cancel with ctrl + c or it goes on forever.

It's much easier than you think, it's just getting used to talking to a window instead of clicking around in GUIs. The nice thing is you can make a list of all your programs and just execute it "sudo apt-get install firefox virtualbox keepassxc ...etc." and it will install it for you. No manual downloads inside a browser, no .exe files, no malware risk, it's just fire and forget.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91439041
Let me tell you how I do it, except i'm doing it for apple and macos instead of microsoft and windows.
1. get a good router that supports openwrt, ddwrt or tomato.
2. block every outgoing dns request that goes to a shitload of domains. There are lists online and if you can't find them you can use a router firewall filter with logging so you see which connections are made and where, and you block them afterwards.
3. you can do the blocking part on the machine but you don't want to do that for each of the machines you have and also, I don't trust windows firewall to block everything you tell him unless you're configured for enterprise. For mac I use littleSnitch.
4. this thing is drastic and it will keep out out of security updates, which might or might not be a good idea. It's a good idea for me because while I have a macbook I use it for 2 things: occasional gaming and virtual machines. I only do my work inside virtual machines (mainly debian but win10 too).
5. i know windows had a nasty habit of daily installing updates, macos is a bit more stable on this, mainly once per year you turn off filtering, reboot your machine and install updates.
If you have questions, please ask.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91444159
>I meant switching anything I want to keep over to an entirely new email address by using the "change my email" feature available on so many different sites and services.

That only ADDS information, it doesn't subtract anything. Your only real option is to ditch and create new accounts that have NO relation to your old ones (different devices, different internet access points, no name attached, etc.).

Information is gathered and associated, so if you introduce "new" things, they are related to old things and thus you only broaden the profile. If you add VPNs, Tor, Protonmail, what have you to the mix, you only make yourself more interesting, not more private.

If you are cool with that, go ahead. But if you aren't, you will have to take much more RL based steps to avoid that association.

For online banking I use a LiveOS like Mint and TAN generator. Nothing else is done on that system, just a freshly booted OS and a quick check of the financials. Banking is pozzed because your real name is attached, so no way of anonymizing it. VPNs, Tor or exotic OSes are red flags in online banking and totally useless for privacy.

I'd separate everything as far as possible. Do banking on a live system, do gaming either offline or online on its own system, work on one machine, hobby stuff on another, etc. PCs are dirt cheap, workstations can be had for 30 bucks.

Everything should be isolated by default, just because. If there is a breach in one thing it remains in that one area, unless you pile up multiple things on one device. Then other stuff is compromised as well. That's why email sucks so much. Use it as throwaway/single use case thing, but not "one for everything". If your gaming PC gets rekt by some discord malware or what have you (Genshin Impact chinese Spyware, the list is long), then only that system is fucked. If you do email, banking, shopping, social media, etc. all on that system too, you now broke all the eggs in that basket. One egg, one basket.

>>91445019
>So I guess that means that anything with my real name attached to it will be linked back to me eventually if I again use my real name (such as in the event I create a new bank account)?

Not just your name, but any identifiable data. Think of it in terms of "="s, that is your IP = your internet access point = your ISP = your name and payment info. Your account = your IP = your name. Once two data points are associated in any way, the connection is there and privacy is lost. This is of course the most extreme example, for nation state actors. But we know big tech companies aggregate just as much information, so the only parties you can have "limited" privacy towards is like... other users that are tech illiterate with a grudge against you? Anyone else draws from these big databases where everything is aggregated in, they don't necessarily collect info themselves.

>How could I handle retaining my phone number though?
Tbh I'd just keep it. Use it for work and be done with it. As for socials, you will never be able to engage with normies (family, friends) in a secure and private way. You'd have to setup special stuff on both ends and ensure all parties are using it correctly, that simply isn't the case. IMO get those fuckers on Signal and be done with it. Google/Apple will be able to read all messages before they are encrypted, but let them have your shitposts. As long as you are not criminally active, you should be fine. Your privacy will be lost of course, but that's the price to pay for instant messaging over the phone. For private matters, meet in person.

I think technology always comes with responsibility and right now it's being exploited by a few actors. People will have to change course eventually, because no amount of privacy measures will be able to make life livable in the hell they're creating right now. >>91445014
I pay for You Need A Budget. It's a little expensive now but I still think it's worth it. The app isn't anything too special but it werks. What is different is the approach to budgeting. You create categories of expenses and items within each category. You can set "goals" for monthly balances, or save up to a certain amount, things like that. The way it works though is that you receive money (say, a paycheque) and you "spend it" by moving all of that money to the different categories.
The psychological effect is real. In your head you don't have any money, it's already spent. Likewise, it isn't depressing to pay bills or whatever you have to because it's as if you have already paid that money out - it's already gone from your perspective.
Anyway, it changed my life. For the first time ever I have savings, I have an emergency fund, and I'm saving money to buy a house with my wife. Can't recommend it enough.

posts.com: how would i go about storing user uploaded images on an s3 with references to the owner of the image? i'm thinking i could either create an entry on an external database with a reference to the image and the user, or i could create a key in the s3 which has the userid as a prefix. what would be the ideal solution? most guides seem to refer to the first option but i never see any good explanation as to why this is more beneficial. in the future i will also need to add more attributes to the image but i was thinking i could add that as metadata to the s3 object rather than populating a db?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91417089
The ideal solution will depend on your use case and requirements, but generally speaking, the first option of having an entry in an external database with a reference to the image and the user is a more common approach.

One of the main benefits of using a database is that it provides a centralized location to store information about the images, such as image metadata, and allows for easier querying and indexing of the data. This makes it easier to search and retrieve information about the images and their owners, as well as to enforce access controls and data management policies.

Using an S3 key prefix with the user ID is an option, but it may not be as flexible or scalable as using a database. With this approach, you would need to write custom code to handle querying and indexing of the data, and it may be harder to enforce access controls and manage data over time.

That being said, storing metadata as S3 object metadata is a common practice, and can be a good solution for smaller datasets. If you expect to have a large number of images, you may need to consider using a database for better scalability and manageability.

Ha! You want to learn PHP? Good luck with that! It's not like there are millions of resources available to help you understand this outdated and completely irrelevant coding language.

Finally, you can always join online communities and forums like Stack Overflow or PHP.net. These are great places to ask questions and get answers from people who actually use PHP on a daily basis. Good luck! You're going to need it!

Would require a linear search + reduce

const books = [
  { title: 'x', author: 'Sue' },
  { tile: 'y', author: 'Jack' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Jack' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Mary' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Sue' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Jack' },
];

// Sort by authors that have written the most books
const authorsByNumBooks = books.reduce(
  (acc, book) => {
    const numBooks = (acc[book.author] || 0) + 1;

    return {
      ...acc,
      [book.author]: numBooks,
      max: acc[acc.max] > numBooks ? acc.max : book.author,
    };
  },
  { max: '' }
);

const authorWithMostBooks = authorsByNumBooks.max;

>>91420368
thanks, just figured it out with lodash when you posted
const mostBlogs = (blogs) => {
  const authors = _.countBy(blogs, 'author');
  const authorCounts = _.map(authors, (val, key) => ({
    author: key,
    blogs: val
  }));

  const maxAuthor = _.max(authorCounts);
  return maxAuthor;
};

i like lodash so far because i'm coming from R and it reminds me of dplyr

Okay, not an exact answer to my question, but since I wanted to declare global variables, this works for me:

index.js:
window.$variable = "My text"


App.js (or other component):
return (
  <h1>{windows.$variable}</h1>
);


Will return:
<h1>My text</h1>


Hope this helps someone else, at least.

It all depends on how you're rendering it.

const myvariable = `My
Text
Example
`;

const paragraphs = myvariable.split("\n").map((line) => {
  const node = document.createElement("p");
  node.innerText = line;
  return node;
});

// render the paragraphs
document.body.append(...paragraphs);

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91433808
What does the console do?
It takes one (1) (ONE) (UNO) (UNE) (一) expression, evaluates it, and prints the result
When you input 
[1, 2, 3].forEach(n => n > 0)
, what you are evaluating is the result of 
[1, 2, 3].forEach(...)
, which is 
undefined
because the return value of forEach is always undefined (https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/forEach#return_value).

You can't reference a single image from an array that contains multiple objects.

const myArray = [
  {
    id: "1",
    title: "Item 1",
    img: "images/image1.jpg",
  },
  {
    id: "2",
    title: "Item 2",
    img: "images/image2.jpg",
  },
];

function Cards() {
  return (
    <div>
      {myArray.map((item) => (
        <Card key={item.id}>
          <Card.Body>
            <Card.Img src={item.img} />
            <Card.Title>{item.title}</Card.Title>
          </Card.Body>
        </Card>
      ))}
    </div>
  );
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91439432
Yeah so there's two ways to use images:

1. Using import syntax like a module. If you're using import syntax, then it needs to be in your src folder. Using import syntax can modify the image contents when building the application, such as converting it to base64, resizing it, etc. For example:
import image from "./image.jpg"

// in your component
<img src={image} />


2. Placing it in your public folder. The public folder is the site root, which means anything in it will be under "/". When you use this method, you can reference the image in img tags using `<img src="/file-name-insite-public-folder.jpg" />`

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91439607
>I assume when you're pushing your repo, you dump the built code (from "npm (run) build") into the public folder and treat the public folder as your root?

How CRA is configured is that it copies all the assets from the public folder, builds all the files in your src folder, and then puts them all inside a "build" folder. It's your job to copy the assets from the build folder to some web host like Vercel or a CDN.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

I don't think you can glob imports using CRA, you can using Vite (import.meta.glob/globEager).

Are there any obvious reasons not to use an SPA for the login page of an OAuth 2 authorization server? Assuming the SPA is served from the same physical server.

The SPA have no problems reading response_type, client_id, etc, and can just add login credentials to before posting it all to the backend before redirecting back to the proper redirect_uri.

I've implemented a simple PoC that works, and I haven't thought of any security implications thus far. The only relevant result I've found on Google is this (mostly) unanswered thread on stack exchange

now, many times I would get a customer and they want to buy a pair of speakers for their TV. great, here's our AV selection, we got klipsch, we got polk, dali, elac, you name it we have it. everything sounds good apart from the jamo (garbage) and elac (disappointing garbage regardless of which tier), you connect these to your AVR and you're good to go. one remote to control them all, it has HDMI CEC and ARC, easy to put up and it integrates into your TV easily

>b-bbut I want a pair of genelecs

okay, you can, but you can't have a decent price AVR with pre-outs. there's this marantz 1509 (I dunno what the current model is) with two channel pre-outs. it has the amp too if you want to connect passive speakers but this baby can run two genelecs (unbalanced RCA). that's too much for you? okay, how about a yamaha WXC-50? decent app, wifi, works well. but you gotta use your phone as a remote or use the shitty credit card shape remote control to adjust sound. nobody wants this. you want balanced XLR outputs for the genelec? pepper your angus, it will cost as much as two G3's. want 5.1 surround? with RCA output that's $1000 + tip

the bluesound node which has HDMI CEC and ARC is shit. the app is shit, the functionality of the machine is shit, the one we have at the office has been in RMA for weeks now. boss wanted a simple one remote system which it offered on paper but oh boy has it been far from it

this is why they buy passive speakers and this is why you don't generally see monitors in the living room

Nyquist-Shannon simply specifies the sampling rate necessary to completely reconstruct given frequencies. It doesn't say anything about the maximum frequency components of sounds that humans could possibly detect.

Conceivably for truly realistic audio you might need frequency response ranging under 1 Hz and over 100 kHz.

>"More to audio than tones" sounds like esoteric bullshit to me
What do you think it means? We don't just detect frequencies but tiny shifts in phase in the way they coincide (which is how we locate direction)

this is untrue. the biggest meme ignorant people like to say and think but it's not true. no matter what the speaker is the only mission is to reproduce sound from the source with the highest fidelity. if you have a pair of "sterile" sounding monitors, they are bad speakers. this is exactly the same stupid shit as "gamer" headsets vs regular headphones. they are literally the same thing, one has an inbuilt mic on it, you can have that same mic with a better sound quality with a modmic

people have the bad habit of comparing something like an LSR 305 to a pair of tower speakers, lets say klipsch RP260F. they sound different because the klipsch is large and when comparing I noticed people tend to turn the passive speakers way up, while people listen to monitors like they know what they are listening to. it's all in their head, it's a load of bullshit. if you really think monitors are "sterile" and to be used only in a studio, you are ignorant

you know the studio has usually at least two kinds of speakers? you might see a pair of genelecs or neumanns in there but then a couple of cheap 5" monitors like the KRK rokit or yamaha HS5. these are bad speakers, they sound weak compared to their competitors like the LSR305 or Eris 5 or pretty much everything else that isn't a rokit or HS. these serve the purpose of being reference of bad speakers. if you mix your music with them to sound good, it will sound good with everything. this is why the NS10 back in the day was found in all studios, it was a shit speaker but mastering the sound on it (not just solely on it) helped you make a better mix, and that still stands today

The difference is that the shitty "consumer acoustics" like the Sony headphones straight up don't play the highs, it's just not there the output is cut off, or the freq curve is so mangled for one specific sound you couldn't even save it with an EQ because it's already jagged as fuck.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91436887
Studio monitors are for studios. A/ they work in small to medium room not giant living rooms B/ they are designed to be close to your ears, within a few feet C/ they consume a shit load of power D/ they need studio gear to work, audio interface, xlr cables, E/ they are heavy as fuck, need studio stands F/ they cost much more than decent home theater floorstanding speakers. Studio monitors are not designed to fill a space with sound, they are intended to transmit the sound directly to your ears as you sit in front of them. This is such a clinical approach, you have to install sound treatment material on your walls to kill the sound reflection, so nothing else reaches your ear except directly from the monitors. You can’t do so much as move a few feet before losing the imaging. This is not so with big ass floorstanding speakers whose intended purpose is to be nondirectional and just to fill a big space evenly with sound.

t. Been there done that. My studio monitors sound muffled from a distance but up close they sound crisp and clear.

Not quite sure what you mean with fixed head, but I got myself an Edwin Jagger safety razor which is quite good and I've been using that for years. You twist on the head basically, but you can also adjust the gap for the blade by not fully twisting it on. >>91434101
It's really simple actually, but it's kind of like cooking where there are a lot of right ways of doing it. The only tool you want is a stick blender to speed up the mixing process, but you can really just stir it very long and end up with the same thing. That's how they made it in the past, just stir the ingredients for a long time until it turns into a yogurt or cream.

The base ingredients for bar soap:
any fat or oil, water (preferably distilled), sodium hydroxide (high purity)
The base ingredients for liquid soap:
any fat or oil, water (preferably distilled), potassium hydroxide (high purity)

Everything else is optional. Depending on the fat or oil you use, the consistency, feel and lather of the soap will differ.

The only difference between bar and liquid soap is the base (sodium/potassium hydroxide). The procedure is basically the same and for both of them you can either do the cold or hot process. Imo start with cold process first, it's easier. Slowly dissolve the base in distilled water (exothermic reaction, wear safety goggles and gloves) and then pour it into the oil and blend it until it's like cream or yogurt.
If you are making bar soap you now pour it into a mold, wait a day or two, remove from mold and let it cure for 4-6 weeks.
If you are making liquid soap you now let it sit a day or two, then slowly add distilled water and mix until you get your desired consistency and then let it cure for 4-6 weeks.

The hot process makes the base react faster with the oil so you can skip the 4-6 weeks curing phase, but you need to cook it right.

There is only one very important thing you have to pay attention to with all soaps regardless of hot or cold process: that you react all of the base with enough oil otherwise the soap will be harsh on your skin. Add 1%-5% more fat or oil (called superfatting) than required and you'll be fine.

I bought these molds so I can make nice even bars of soap but they are optional too.

• Senn HD 600/650/6XX (neutral but partly veiled treble, flat bass) - $240+
• DCA Expanse (neutral V) - $4000

Recommended gaming headsets:
• A good headphone paired with a mic
• Beyer MMX 300 (bright V, same as DT 770) - $230
Honorable mentions:
• HyperX Cloud II (bright V) - $80
• CM MH751/752 (neutral V) - $75

Recommended DAC/amp:
• US market Apple Dongle - $10 (you probably don't need more than this)
Honorable mentions:
• Topping DX1 - $100
• Topping DX3 Pro+ - $200
• SMSL C200 - $200
• FiiO K7 - $200
• RME ADI-2 (many DSP features) - $1200

>I can't appreciate old-looking desktops, no matter how hard I try
That's okay! Not everyone has to appreciate the same things. Personal preferences and tastes can vary greatly from person to person. What's important is that you find what you enjoy and what brings you happiness. If old-looking desktops don't do it for you, that's perfectly fine.

It's also worth noting that different people value different things in a desktop setup. For some, a minimalist and clean look might be most important, while for others it could be a more customized and personalized appearance. What's important is that you have a setup that meets your needs and makes you happy.

So, don't worry about not appreciating old-looking desktops. Focus on what you do enjoy and make your setup reflect that.

How can I tell if this is a fake? The keys are not hotswappable, and I'm aware of fake mechanical keyboards that have blue or red switches pressing down on a rubber membrane. I did a test where I pressed down on 3 keys at once and it would only register 2, I tried this in multiple video games, I also pressed all the way to the bottom with multiple keys and it felt like it was a rubber dome. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91441331
Uhh are you saying that the pic and the keyboard in the link is the same? Then yes, that keyboard is a fake. Switches are supposed to be soldered into a PCB, yet what you're looking at is rubber underneath.
If your issue is just the amount of registering keys, don't worry about that. Just means your keyboard is 2kro (2 key rollover), meaning super cheap keyboard (hope you didnt pay too much for it). If you're still wary but don't want to open up your keyboard, you can use a switch puller. Putting reasonable force will make it pop out easily because there's no connection. It won't pop out if it's an actual mech keyboard because it's soldered.

Fuck!

Does there need to be a new approach to reinvent programming languages as a whole? Seriously, you can waste hours, weeks or even months on simple problems autistically to be as optimized as possible (how Cniles prefer it). I'm not encouraging more layers of abstraction bloat that would burn your CPU, I just think it's silly and makes people turn away from programming, accidentally losing their old solutions and having to reapproach the same problem all over again from scratch as if you were to reinvent the wheel.

I used an old 250GB HDD as a storage drive for another PC since games are getting huge and the 250GB SSD wasn't enough.
I had some corrupt files on a fresh install of a game via Steam that caused a game to crash, so I did some investigating and found the drive had a pending sector in SMART. I then proceeded to zero fill the drive then do a surface read test, and no reallocated sectors showed up but then after installing some games again some pending sectors came back. Then disappeared.
This annoyed the hell out of me so I booted linux and ran badblocks -wsv on the drive. On the first pass it had (2/0/0) errors but no SMART values went up. I ran it through 5 more complete badblocks -wsv tests (4-patterns each, so it did write+read tests 20+ more times) and they all came back fine with (0/0/0) errors. No SMART values went up.

It doesn't seem to want to remap out the bad bits despite running into errors that the OS can detect and Steam's verify file integrity tool showed corruption.
CrystalDiskInfo shows the health status as good.
>0 Reallocated Sectors
>0 Current Pending Sector Count
>0 Uncorrectable Sector Count
>0 CRC Error Count 0
>0 Reallocation Event Count

Is this drive garbage despite its ability to pass badblocks and good SMART status?

>>91444874
One of the greatest experiences I ever had in my life was on Kelbaker Road, right off of I-40 in the mojave desert in California.
I used to drive a truck, and I would regularly drive from Indianapolis to Los Angeles and back again. I had to stop and take care of a flickering pigtail so I stopped off on kelbaker rd at 2am, in summer, on a perfectly clear night, and it was the first time I really bothered to get out of the truck anywhere that far away from civilization up until this point, there’s no real reason to any other time.
I stepped out of that truck and after turning it off experienced two things
>natural silence
>zero light pollution
Kelbaker is lower than the expressway, and even then 40 at 2am in the desert isn’t too busy. There was no noise that wasn’t just the breeze over sand. And then looking up and seeing an unrestricted night sky for the first time in my life was such an unfathomably eye opening experience, I stayed out there for about an hour just enjoying silence and stars.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91445033
As much as the experience with the visuals of the complete night sky has stuck with me, it’s the silence that I want the most.
After being in complete natural silence, not artificial silence, there’s still sound, just ever so subtle and muted in creation of nature, I cannot stop hearing unnatural background noise.
If you don’t know of actual silence your brain just tunes out background noise, the local roads, neighbors air conditioning units, the sound of your water heater, electrical whine, planes in the distance. You can sit in what you perceive as silence simply because your brain doesn’t care about the background noise, but it is there. And once you have a frame of reference of actual silence, it ruins everything else.
There is a semi industrial highway 4 miles north of me and I can fully hear trucks driving down it from time to time as the sound bounces off my neighbors house and is audible through the glass of my windows. I would kill to live in the type of natural quiet I experienced.

>Tortoise TTS stack: Learn what it does. Suggest improvements. Compare it to 11 labs.
1) Autoregressive transformer stack predicts discrete speech "tokens" given a text prompt. (Like DALLE using GPT but with speech)
2) CLIP model judges autoregressive transformer outputs against the text ranking the most probable.
3) Speech tokens are decoded into a low-quality MEL spectrogram using a VQVAE.
4) UNet diffusion model decodes VQVAE output into raw audio wav file using openAI ImprovedDiffusion.
>Tortoise is basically OpenAI's DALLE, applied to speech data.

>What can you do: Look for code improvements in these forks, report back
https://github.com/neonbjb/tortoise-tts/network/members

NEWS: NEW GOOGLE PAPER JUST PUBLISHED: SpearTTS
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.03540.pdf
>is the end result of their earlier research? https://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.04558.pdf

Speak, Read and Prompt: High-Fidelity Text-to-Speech with Minimal Supervision
We introduce SPEAR-TTS, a multi-speaker text-to-speech (TTS) system that can be trained with minimal supervision. By combining two types of discrete speech representations, we cast TTS as a composition of two sequence-to-sequence tasks: from text to high-level semantic tokens (akin to "reading") and from semantic tokens to low-level acoustic tokens ("speaking"). Decoupling these two tasks enables training of the "speaking" module using abundant audio-only data, and unlocks the highly efficient combination of pretraining and backtranslation to reduce the need for parallel data when training the "reading" component. To control the speaker identity, we adopt example prompting, which allows SPEAR-TTS to generalize to unseen speakers using only a short sample of 3 seconds, without any explicit speaker representation or speaker-id labels. Our experiments demonstrate that SPEAR-TTS achieves a character error rate that is competitive with state-of-the-art methods using only 15 minutes of parallel data, while matching ground-truth speech in terms of naturalness and acoustic quality, as measured in subjective tests.

HivemindStrategy in PyTorch Lightning allows adapting your existing pipelines to training over slow network with unreliable peers.


>Hivemind
>Distributed training without a master node: >Distributed Hash Table allows connecting computers in a decentralized network.
>Fault-tolerant backpropagation: forward and backward passes succeed even if some nodes are unresponsive or take too long to respond.
>Decentralized parameter averaging: iteratively aggregate updates from multiple workers without the need to synchronize across the entire network
>Train neural networks of arbitrary size: parts of their layers are distributed across the participants with the Decentralized Mixture-of-Experts.

posts.com:
>>91411461
This is how anons are doing stable diffusion collaborative training. It would be good to discuss the best collaborative AI training methods as many point out anons don't have individual resource
https://github.com/chavinlo/distributed-diffusion
>SAIL discord
https://discord.gg/8Sh2T6gjd2
>How they do P2P swarm training
1. Dataset
Currently code expect dataset to be in form of image jpg,jpeg,webp,png and accompanying json file that contains tags i.e danbooru dataset. Currently it's hardcoded and will be used as example one for that guide.
Sqlite db is stored in repo as index of files, and files served from linode bucket in pairs, there is check in code to discard non paired images. During training, both image and json are fetched, and from json extracted only description tags and saved as txt file alongside image in workplace directory.
2. Mother node
Currently it expects to have GPU and will be part of the swarm. For distributed training you also need configuration in next step.
3. Relay mode
Next step is to set up relay configuration in UI, that will allow your node to serve config endpoint to peers - from wich they will be able to grab config, for that purprose I.E port are used. So if you behind NAT it makes sense to portforward port 80 to your internal I.E port, TCP ports are used for DHT connections so as well needed to be portforwarded, and your public ip will be used as DHT server, so that ip (or domain name ) you can spread among peers so they would be able to join swarm.
If you are NOT behind NAT, put matching pairs of ports here, so advertised and listened ports are matched and that will do the trick.
4. Training
After configuration and start of training, there will be main events after 1200 seconds i.e 20 minutes
Optimizer and Averager events should start and peers will exchange trained weights - that should lead to decrease in loss.
Due to geography and network speeds, and size of weights that part may be tricky so keep an eye on that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
VITS two stage training
>https://arxiv.org/pdf/2106.06103.pdf
>Conditional Variational Autoencoder with Adversarial Learning for End-to-End Text-to-Speech
Several recent end-to-end text-to-speech (TTS) models enabling single-stage training and parallel sampling have been proposed, but their sample quality does not match that of two-stage TTS systems. In this work, we present a parallel end-to-end TTS method that generates more natural sounding audio than current two-stage models. Our method adopts variational inference augmented with normalizing flows and an adversarial training process, which improves the expressive power of generative modeling. We also propose a stochastic duration predictor to synthesize speech with diverse rhythms from input text. With the uncertainty modeling over latent variables and the stochastic duration predictor, our method expresses the natural one-to-many relationship in which a text input can be spoken in multiple ways with different pitches and rhythms. A subjective human evaluation (mean opinion score, or MOS) on the LJ Speech, a single speaker dataset, shows that our method outperforms the best publicly available TTS systems and achieves a MOS comparable to ground truth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm unironically impressed by how good tortoise does at replicating the male Imperial voice from Morrowind. The latent was built ~180 samples from Morrowind's datafiles, each 2-5 seconds in length:
using fast preset reading a copypasta (cant remember render time): https://voca.ro/130xBfm9ULiw (embed)
ultra fast preset, sneedpasta: https://voca.ro/12KaK9kDBEi2 (embed)
ultra fast preset reading a book from Oblivion (took about 6 minutes to generate on a 4090 as I didn't want to wait an hour): https://vocaroo.com/14qgBk1iOjcX (embed)

Link to the latent + dataset: https://files.catbox.moe/s4il3l.zip

From what I can tell, deeper clear bass/baritone voices map better to male voices and are less likely to jump into random english girl mode. I would assume similar for higher pitched female voices. Voices that are more dynamic tend to break more.

>>91425595
this should get you started on tortoise
https://huggingface.co/jbetker/tortoise-tts-v2
Adding a new voice
To add new voices to Tortoise, you will need to do the following:
Gather audio clips of your speaker(s). Good sources are YouTube interviews (you can use youtube-dl to fetch the audio), audiobooks or podcasts. Guidelines for good clips are in the next section.
Cut your clips into ~10 second segments. You want at least 3 clips. More is better, but I only experimented with up to 5 in my testing.
Save the clips as a WAV file with floating point format and a 22,050 sample rate.
Create a subdirectory in voices/
Put your clips in that subdirectory.
Run tortoise utilities with --voice=<your_subdirectory_name>.

posts.com:
Google's spear tts
The key benefit of splitting the TTS task into
these two sub-tasks is that the supervision needed to learn how to map text into the intermediate semantic token representation (“reading”) and how to produce speech from it (“speaking”) become decoupled. While the “reading” stage relies on parallel text-audio data, the audio tokens used to train the “speaking” component are produced by self-supervised audio models and therefore can be extracted from a massive amount of unlabeled speech data. As a result, the quality and diversity of the generated speech become independent from
the available parallel data.

We take inspiration from BART and T5 and pre-
train an encoder-decoder Transformer on a denoising pretext task

this is some of the tech stack google seems to be using, in tandem
https://huggingface.co/docs/transformers/model_doc/bart

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91443786
>directstorage
This generation's marketing term following the footsteps of Sega's blast processing.

>DirectStorage for Windows replaces the Win32 FileIO API with a new API designed for very high numbers of small file requests. This allows modern games to get their assets out of storage much quicker and to saturate the high bandwidth of NVMe SSDs. The IO requests are still submitted by the CPU. (Edit: It’s worth mentioning that these requests are much easier to handle than traditional IO requests because a lot of the work is done by NVMe hardware queues, which is why DirectStorage is so much faster on NVMe drives.) The compressed assets are loaded into system memory, just like before. The assets are decompressed by the CPU, just like before, and then copied over to VRAM, just like before.

>Again, in its current state, DirectStorage for Windows does not bypass the CPU or system memory for graphics file IO.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Although buying a CRT is cheaper today, the problem is that it's becoming harder to find good CRTs, as hundreds still get dumped at the recycle everyday (even in 2023, businesses clearing them out and residents clearing their attics in spring cleaning), reducing the number of CRTs available on the used market.
In ten or fifteen years, it will be far easier to get a 4K 500Hz OLED display that does a more more accurate spatial & temporal job of emulating a Sony PVM CRT than a worn-out semi-misconverged CRT that you had to drive hours to pick up. 4K 240Hz has already arrived (LCD). But, OLED/MicroLED can really compensate to the point where 240Hz OLED looks clearer motion than 360Hz LCD (the OLED advantage is about 1.5x to 2.0x refresh rate, thanks to lack of visible GtG blurring added to the MPRT blurring). Samsung demoed a 240Hz OLED so 240Hz OLED panels are not far behind. If you've seen MAME HLSL on a 4K 60Hz OLED screen, you already know that it looks fantastic--how the 4K is a massive improvement to CRT filter simulation. At this point, every phosphor dot on NTSC CRTs now becomes visible. To get "Sufficiently superior to a used CRT in the 2030s used resale market"--we do not really need to go straight to retina 8K and 1000Hz, superior-on-average-to-a-worn-CRT in all checklist (color, gamut, blacks, texture simulation, temporal simulation, etc, etc) is likely doable at 4K 500Hz, especially if it's OLED/MicroLED instead.
Good BFI can still benefit from 1000Hz+ displays of the future, too. The holy grail would be display emulators (CRT electron beam emulator, plasma display emulator, etc) that piggyback on the sheer Hz for accurate temporal display emulation (including low blur, softer rolling flicker, phosphor decay, etc) and does whatever temporal technology is needed to comfortably reduce display motion blur. Emulating a CRT electron beam in software requires sheer Hz. e.g. using 16 digital refresh cycle to emulate 1 CRT refresh cycle.

To be fair, the majority of CRTs have phosphor ghosting. They just lack sample and hold blur (CRTs are impulsed displays) which is a huge win over flat panels.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91443298
It's more of a feature than a bug though. It reduces flicker by a whole lot, making even 60hz actually viable to use. On an LCD that lacks decay and rolling scan, the strobe is so much harsher and eyestraining to use.
And the phosphor decay doesn't even affect the clarity of the primary image, and the trails are only visible in rather limited scenarios. You can only see it on light-to-black transitions, only when you're moving your eyes on the screen.
It's a surprisingly good thing when you weight all the pros and cons.

Also, excuse me for uttering this word, but it's also pure soul. The few reminders you have left on high-end CRTs that you're still using something rather arcane. Pleasant phosphor glow.

>>91444148
Not really true, unfortunately. 1000hz = 1ms of motion persistence IF you have 1000 pixels/second motion. So, at 4k, you need ~3840hz.
https://blurbusters.com/blur-busters-law-amazing-journey-to-future-1000hz-displays-with-blurfree-sample-and-hold/#viciouscycle
>The Vicious Cycle Effect means a higher resolution display makes it easier to see motion blur.
>Higher resolution means more pixels to motionblur over
>Wider FOV means more time to track moving objects
>Closer viewing distance means easier to see motion blur
>8K display panning 1 screenwidth per second = about 8 pixels of motion blur at 1ms MPRT.
>8K 60Hz motion blur is godawful -- 128 pixels of display motion blur at 60Hz, if you're tracking your eyes on panning motions. 7680 pixels/sec pan, divided by 60Hz, equals 128 pixel jump between frames, which is the persistence.

Anons are scared about compiling but don't realize you don't have to watch over the machine while it's doing it's thing. You can sleep or touch grass while updating. With a processor made in the last 10 years you can just keep using it too,

But you can just use Nix on Gentoo :)

If you're going to use the same system for several years, as you should, Gentoo is absolutely worth it.

pm disable-user com.samsung.android.game.gos
pm disable-user com.sec.android.smartfpsadjuster

>>91424853
He obviously means `sudo ansible` which is a big no-no.

>>91424810
Ansible is supposed to have access to the files it needs to copy. You missed this step when writing your playbooks or roles.
Copy the stuff from /etc/letsencrypt into <playbook_root>/files/, or add their contents as host_vars, or stick them into an encrypted vault (since the key is secret).
When writing a playbook or a role, design it from the perspective of "this stuff will run from a live CD", don't rely on the presence of anything outside the playbook directory, maybe with the exception of an SSH key.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91439235
You used a separate compositor with i3 and it's the compositor that's doing that, not i3.

With Sway, Sway _is_ the compositor and it can set opacity but has no way to target inactive windows with rules so you need a script to do that. It's still Sway setting the opacity, the script just communicates with Sway via IPC ($SWAYSOCK, which is a UNIX socket) to tell it what windows to effect.

OLED, because mini LED is just an LCD with small backlight zones. You still get backlight bleed, just less of it, but now it forms a halo around bright things since the zones are larger than a pixel. OLED gives you pure blacks with no bleed and no halo.

Personally I'd rather have a normal LCD than mini LED. My eyes get used to a constant static backlight bleed across the image after a few minutes, and tune it out. Halos around bright things that move around in a chunk-chunk-chunk pattern as bright things move between backlight zones makes it much harder to tune out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91438810
You are perhaps confusing it with Micro LED. "Mini LED" is an LED backlit LCD with fairly small backlight zones. "OLED" is one LED per subpixel, but they're organic LEDs, which reduces manufacturing complexity and cost, but also reduces lifespan. "Micro LED" is the same deal as OLED, but they're traditional inorganic LEDs that last longer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
After watching Karoly's video I got inspired to actually read the VALL-E paper
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F6HSsVIkqIU
Useful information:
They use the LibriLight dataset which is 60,000 hours of speech which they had to transcript using another model

It is different from Tortoise in that they generate the input for another model (EnCodec) rather than a Mel Spectrogram, which makes it orders of magnitude more computationally efficient than Tortoise, which uses Diffusers to generate the spectrogram.
Diffusers require multiple steps to generate an output and this is what makes them inherently slow.

VALL-E is trained on phoneme sequences, which makes it an oddity because most models are trained on text input.

This is a weakness IMO and applies limitations to prompt engineering. You are not going to easily be able to transcript "SNIIFFFFFFF" into phonemes.
Phoneme mappings are hard to come by in low-resource languages (anything that is not English), and even in English there are multiple mappings for dialects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91433545
I think its a diffusion model thing. The text can get in the way of learning if the encoding isn't done right. The phoneme approach is treats the chunks of sound as sequences to be predicted, that's why it sounds more natural after the diffusion models got better. AFAIK Tortoise makes use of spectrograms. Google SPEAR-TTS is brand new, I think it got released last week, and again is based on a diffusion model.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91433545
I guess an advantage to the phoneme mapping approach is that it'd be possible to make models for foreign language voice actors, since the model is tied to the phonemes and not the language.

It's a huge bitch in any other way though. You'd almost need a model that can interpret your voice and transcript it into phonemes.

>>91435829
Unironically ask chatgpt, it's super good at explaining and will walk you through writing your own implementation from scratch.
As far as I can tell it's pretty much a multilayer preceptron where each layer has these extra "attention" weights where you dot the activations with the attention and then convolve that over the input (by dotting) and sum up all of that, softmax it, and hand it to the next layer.
Then you take the output and hand it to pretty much the same thing but with different weights and the attention looks at both the output of the last thing and its own output.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: What you're referring to as Linux, is in fact, Windows Subsystem for Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, WSL. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free app in the Microsoft Store and part of a fully functioning Windows system made useful by the Windows OS, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX. Many computer users run a modified version of the WSL system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of WSL which is widely used today is often called "Linux", and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the Windows system, developed by Microsoft. There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the app: the program in the system that wastes the machine's resources to limit the other programs that you run. The app is an optional part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete Windows operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the Windows operating system: the whole system is basically Windows with Linux added, or WSL. All the so-called "Linux" apps are really flavors of WSL.

>>91436815
>unless you're on nvidia and want to use an external display with your laptop
No it works, but it takes a little tinkering. All distros except probably PopOS suffer from this problem, and I didn't use an external monitor when I used Fedora so I don't know so maybe.
I know this because I used to use Arch and Mint and they both had these problems, Ubuntu had this problem but this is how I solved it on Novideo Optimoose laptop with Xorg.

1. Install proprietary drivers.
Noveau is shit and causes slowdowns and other problems with external monitors.

2. Install Nvidia X Server settings.
For some reason this doesn't come preinstalled with the Nvidia driver on Linux like it does on Windows.

3. Go into X Server settings, PRIME settings and change (Hybrid) to (Performance Mode)
This eliminates the slowdowns experienced when setting an external display as the primary monitor.

4. (Only applicable if you use Steam) Go into /usr/share/applications/steam.desktop and change "PrefersNonDiscreteGPU = True" to "PrefersNonDiscrete = GPU = False".

I've never used PopOS but given that System76's laptops run on Novideo Optimoose I'm guessing they've already done this.
Either way.
Yeah Ubuntu takes SOME tinkering for niche cases like this but for most people, including for most things, it just werks.

posts.com:
Users of all levels welcome. Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>Which W10 version should I install?
Home/Pro: No, comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps.
Education/Workstation/Enterprise: Yes, but comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only): Yes, but comes with Win32 system utils, limited system apps like Settings and Notification area, no MS Store. If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS can trip your AV and deactivate. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something. If you know what you're doing:

https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>As a client–server protocol, SMB requires a server service (LanmanServer) and a client service (LanmanWorkstation). posts.name: Faggot OP
posts.com:
>>91418368
Strictly speaking, you don't need LanmanServer to access a network drive (and it's in fact turned off on a lot of enterprise machines for this reason).
You'd probably want the Function Discovery services too, because they populate the Network Neighbourhood icon, otherwise you're stuck with having to type \\Server\Share into the Map Network Drive dialog, File Explorer's address bar, etc. - but like the Server service, they aren't actually required.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91422830
>Harddisk4
Was set up with a tool you specifically told that you would never boot from the drive, so you didn't get an ESP at all.
>Harddisk5
Was set up under either Vista or 7 disk management. They used a 100MB ESP - later versions of Windows use progressively larger default ESP sizes, but are thus far always divisible by 100.
>Harddisk6
Was set up with a possibly Linux/FOSSshit partitioning tool, as they seem to like powers of 2 - so you get system partition sizes like 128MB or 512MB instead of 100MB or 500MB.
>If my partition tables get wiped by accident would the backup headers contain all the info to still let me mount the volumes
The backup GPT is stored in the last few sectors of a drive, where they're safe from dskwipe, dd etc. unless you let them run to completion. In practice though, when you start from absolute sector 0 and start blasting data, you don't generally stop when you hit the first partition, and there's some pretty important data stored in the early sectors of partitions.
While both GPT (as mentioned) and NTFS back up their important data elsewhere, to my knowledge, nothing uses them automatically - you'll need some sort of tool to recover the backup GPT or $MFTMir.

If you've logged in with an MS account (which you shouldn't be if you care about privacy let's be fair) the HWID that's created by MAS is connected to that account, which means that if you change any parts in your PC your computer will stay activated if you log in with said account.
