It's actually not even really black magic, just tricky code using legit Windows tools to make the install believe it just updated from 7 to 10, which gives you instant forever activation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
ITT, we discuss alternative operating systems and alternative ISA.

We discuss alternatives to Windows, Mac and Linux, such as SerenityOS, Haiku, GNU/HURD, AmigaOS/AROS and rare BSDs, as well homebrew projects and operating system development.
We also we discuss non-x86 ISAs from the past (6502, 68000, Alpha, Itanium, PA-RISC, PowerPC, SuperH, VAX, Z80, PDP-11), the present (ARM, MIPS, POWER, SPARC) and the future (RISC-V, OpenPOWER).

You can also ask here for more information. Don't forget to check out the wiki, by the way!

>AIG Wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aig/_Alternative_ISA_General
>AOSG wiki: https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki//aosg/_Alternative_Operating_System_General

>>91432375
I'm not sure I'm informed enough to do a good job at a design that's completely my own yet. I could definitely try and then look at others if I do anything stupid and feel I'm up against a wall.
I was already experimenting with designing my own filesystem. Trouble is, it's really not easy to do it efficient. My objectives were:
1. Journalled
2. Transparent compression
3. Multiple filesets
I wanted snapshots (fast ones, like in ZFS) as well, but that's really tricky. How do you do them properly? I was thinking of, instead of having a block bitmap, having a block "bytemap", where each slot in the map is a reference count instead of a use-bit; and then if e.g. you need to modify an inode, you've got to check if the block to which the inode belongs has a refcount >1; if so, you need to copy the whole block that the inode is on. It's all really quite confusing to me.

I've been thinking about this a lot and kept looking at ARMs over the years. They all suck. Sorry, but it is just true. Way too expensive for what they are and a used 5-6-7 year old intel/amd will be magnitudes better while usually being a lot cheaper, too. Some of the 5W TDP Core M-era SoCs don't really consume much more power (and often even less) than high-end ARM too.

I mean on paper they all look nice, yes. The hardware support just isn't ever coming and as soon as it starts to materialize for one SoC, another one comes out and the devs drop it like a hot potato and start over from zero.

ARM is a meme.

I totally get that pleasant, comfy feel of having a low end machine that just covers all the uses cases, sips on electricity and maybe doesn't even have a single fan, with a very minimalist OS on top. I fulfilled that wish for myself by buying a Thinkpad Gen2 tablet and putting it on a stand with USB hub, with a very nice mech keyboard in front of it. Threw in a 1 TB drive because why not? Absolutely sucks as a tablet, is amazing as tiny, fanless desktop PC. Maybe think in that direction? Screen's gorgeous too.

>>91439916
no, just saw the prices slowly but steadily rising 10+ years ago. The Amiga I got in the 80s as a kid, I just decided to fulfill all my childhood dreams when that stuff was still relatively cheap. Bought tons of retrocomputing stuff in the 00s and early 10s when the consooming wasn't in full force and many still considered it junk. One of my A500s I got for five euros. I don't even know the prices now. Feel I'd be worried about turning my A2000 on if I did and it'd suck the fun out of it all. They're probably insane. lol

I remember when I switched from workbench and Amiga goodness to a 486 and DOS/Win 3.1 and while I appreciated the wider gaming palette it also immediately felt like a step back. Switched to Linux in ~2002 and it was ok but peak Amiga comfiness was never reached again. Then as an adult I got really into AmigaOS internals from a poweruser standpoint and things like ARexx scripting and couldn't believe how shit everything is today in comparsion. I actually don't do much with my A2000 anymore because a 060 is such overkill for everything, nowadays I spent most of my time with an relatively unexpanded (just some FastRAM) A600, but I kinda want to deck out one of my A1200s I have lying around. (With a Blizzard card and a Delfina soundcard) I'm not really up to the newest retro tech so that might be interesting. I feel the A1200 might be more at a sweet spot in terms of speed and I could remote into an ARM Linux box for a lot of stuff. Maybe I'll buy one of the Checkmate cases.

I also have decked out 040 Performa I really adore. These old OSes are actually really nice to use if you don't care about browsing. Tons of good application software.

ChatGPT on why Socialism sucks donkey dick:
There is significant debate among economists and political scientists about why socialism has failed in some cases. Some of the common reasons cited include:

- Incentives: In a socialist system, the government controls the means of production and there is often little incentive for individuals to work hard and be productive. This can lead to inefficiencies, low productivity, and a lack of innovation.

- Bureaucracy: Socialism can lead to the creation of large bureaucracies that are responsible for running the economy and allocating resources. This can lead to red tape, slow decision-making, and a lack of accountability.

- Central planning: In a socialist system, the government is responsible for making all important economic decisions, such as what to produce and how to produce it. This can lead to the misallocation of resources and the production of goods and services that are not in line with consumer demand.

- Price distortions: In a socialist system, prices are often set by the government rather than by market forces. This can lead to price distortions, which can result in shortages and surpluses of certain goods and services.

- Lack of flexibility: Socialism can make it difficult for the economy to adjust to changes in consumer demand or technological progress. This can result in economic stagnation and a lack of growth.

- Corruption: In some cases, socialism has been associated with corruption, as those in positions of power may abuse their authority for personal gain.

It is worth noting that different socialist systems have been implemented in different ways and have had varying levels of success. Additionally, some of the criticisms of socialism are also criticisms of certain implementations of socialism, rather than of the idea of socialism itself.

ChatGPT on why the Labor Theory of Value doesn't work in a market based economy which is how the world has always worked-

The Labor Theory of Value is an economic theory that argues that the value of a good is determined by the amount of labor that goes into producing it. This theory was popular in the 19th century and was a central part of classical economics.

However, in a market economy, the Labor Theory of Value is often considered to be incorrect for several reasons:

- Neglects demand: The Labor Theory of Value does not take into account the role of demand in determining the value of a good. In a market economy, the value of a good is determined by both the supply of the good and the demand for the good. If there is high demand for a good, the value of the good will be higher, even if the amount of labor that goes into producing it is low.

- Ignores the role of capital: The Labor Theory of Value does not take into account the role of capital in production. Capital, such as machines and buildings, can greatly increase productivity and efficiency. The value of a good is not only determined by the amount of labor that goes into producing it, but also by the amount of capital that is used in production.

- Does not account for differences in skill: The Labor Theory of Value assumes that all labor is equal in terms of value, but this is not the case in reality. Different workers have different levels of skill and experience, and some workers are able to produce more value in the same amount of time than others.

- Does not reflect market realities: The Labor Theory of Value does not reflect the reality of how markets work. In a market economy, prices are determined by supply and demand, and prices are constantly changing as a result of changes in market conditions. The Labor Theory of Value does not account for this dynamic nature of markets.

>>91432309
>Please give examples of what's not possible with OpenOffice or LibreOffice
It'd be cool if I'm wrong on this, maybe you can tell me, but as far as I've been able to find, there's no way to make LibreOffice Calc's conditional formatting work the way Excel's does.

Conditional formatting in Excel changes only the elements of a cell you tell it to change, e.g. "make the background color red if the value is greater than 3"
Conditional formatting in LibreOffice Calc applies an entire style to the cell
That means that in Excel you can apply conditional formatting to a range of cells that have a variety of existing formatting without altering any of that formatting besides the individual elements you actually want to change, whereas in Calc you'll end up with ugly style clashes on cells that don't have the same formatting as the one you created the conditional formatting style from.

>i can't say NIGGER over there and because i'm still in my edgy 14 year old phase (despite being in my mid-20s) i don't like it. you see, i can't express myself unless i can say racial slurs to filter out normies or some other gay shit cope like that

is HN perfect? of course not. there's tons of bloviating over there. but there's much, much more pertinent discussions over there than this place has had in probably over a decade. there's no soijak spam, there's no 50 daily bait threads screeching about trannies, there's little repetitive OS console warring. there's no reddit-tier meme comments because they're downvoted to oblivion (or outright removed). HN's SNR is incomparable to 4chan's.

the simple fact of the matter is that *some* moderation is needed for online communities to work. online communities live and die by their leadership/moderation/admins/etc. 4chan is an example that continues to prove itself every day that near-non-existent moderation doesn't work. for nearly a decade now, every board is groundhog day that rehashes the same bait worded slightly different. people whining about reddit being full of meme comments should realize this place is no different; the more outrageous the bait, the more (You)s it gets. derailing a thread is incredibly easy. one dedicated autist can derail an entire board if they please while the non-existent jannies do nothing.

>>91440792
One potential option is to have pseudonymous accounts, where the usernames are hidden from posts. Each thread would assign a temporary username to the poster (similar to the IDs used on pol). This way you could still moderate by account, but users would not accumulate meaningful karma or reputation. (some kind of hidden feedback system might work though)

I like 4chan's anonymity all the way down, but you could defeat the karma/reputation system without eliminating accounts altogether. Users could still be able to look at their own post history, even. But the format would encourage anonymity for the sake of keeping topics focused. (Hacker News even has some designs in this direction, significantly de-emphasizing the prominence of usernames compared to what was common in forums at the time.)

Recently (as in the past few weeks) I've been thinking about and observing the volumes of information that flow through different technology communities (/g/, subreddits, HN, etc.) and how it ties into the quality of the sites.
HN on average gets a new thread every 1-2 minutes. On a fast day it can get 1440 new threads, or close to ten full /g/ catalogs of content. The upvote/downvote nature of the site means that most of these new articles will never, ever see the light of the front page, even if they are incredibly fascinating and in-line with the name of the site "Hacker News" (A misnomer really). This is because in order to reach the front page they need to reach a threshold of momentum which is very hard to get unless you use bots, make an article on a "hot" topic that people are bound to interact with ([FAGMAN company] does [Thing] / Elon Musk / Blog spam), and/or simply get lucky. Its very similar to Reddit in this way. Its an extremely unfair system that does not reward interesting topics and incentivizes cheating. 4chan completely blows Reddit and Hacker News out of the water by not only having a neutral catalog system but by also having image support which allows for far greater expression and creativity. Wading through the entire catalog on /g/ in one sitting isn't easy. Wading through the entire set of threads posted in one day on HN is impossible.

REPOSTING (again....):
computer architecture prof just told us it's better to manually edit code to ensure your loops don't overflow the cache because modern compilers aren't good enough to handle this
this feels antithetical to everything i have learned, but he seems to think that compilers all suck. are compilers actually that bad? feels hard to believe

e.g.
we have an 8 block by 8 block array that we're looping though, and we're looping though it some number of times with various K values
if the cache is only, say, 8x4, so 32 blocks in size, then the way the first set of loops is set up, the cache will have the useful data removed by the time we get back to the first index of the array, and every memory access will be a miss. but if we instead break it up into fully completing half of the array at a time, there is enough room to keep all of the data in the cache and not have any misses (aside from the first round of compulsory misses)

posts.com:
Spent basically all day tracking down a bug in my compiler in the implementation of module loading. It was a very simple issue, too. It's a native-code jit compiler and I was moving the executable memory pointer only after I executed the function I had just compiled. When that function was the module load function, which itself compiles the module and thus displaces the codeptr, it ends up writing on the wrong spot because the ptr hadn't yet been updated. Oops!
While I was at it I changed from my heap-oriented parameter allocation to a more limited by cleaner round-robin register allocation scheme.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91437776
You basically should never mess with prediction annotations like likely/unlikely and instead do source-level transformations. Modern branch predictors are absolutely ridiculously complex in how they can predict things. They can even detect staggered patterns that you can't express with likely/unlikely. Instead it's far more important for a path to BE likely or unlikely and to adjust the code to make it so. Trying to annotate it is going to fuck the predictor up and slow everything down a lot almost always in practice.
>other
restrict, const, volatile (anti-optimization), [[gnu::always_inline/no_inline]] (another one you shouldn't do), [[gnu::hot]] [[gnu::const]] [[noreturn]], and general constness counts, too.

>>91442178
That's not how it works, buddy. The operating system takes care of all those details for you, you don't have to worry about any of that. All you have to worry about is having a reasonably sized buffer on which you can copy what you're receiving and understanding when to stop. When read() errors (returns -1) and sets errno to EAGAIN it means there's nothing more to read at that moment. And if read() returns 0 it means the connection was gracefully shudown.

https://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man2/read.2.html

>>91440274
you can make loading assets on a thread while showing a loading screen.
multiplayer networking benefits spliting your logic and network IO into difference thread because if you have a really long halt on the main thread, it wont stall your network connection / logic (there used to be a really annoying problem on windows 7 where if you dragged your window, it would freeze your main thread).
There's a bit that you can use threads for rendering for a 3D game, but I don't consider that a game anymore, that's more of a game engine, and with an engine you can avoid using threads since it does everything for you.

>>91407372
>Does anyone know how to get it to deliver the lines in a specific way?
What I found yesterday, is that creating duplicates of the dataset, (ie, anonvoice1, anonvoice2) and actually having a specific dataset for a particular speech pattern, can help. And you can do this without gutting your original dataset, and if you stay on the same seed, you flick between them and see if it sounds any better or avoids the Britishness. I don't know how latents work, but there's no way they're getting 200mb of speech down to 10kb - hence, I think splitting it up and keeping strong emotions isolated might help.

The bigger problem I think, is that no matter what, the audiobooks bleed in and give everything an unsettling calm. itoddler probably talks like that, but models trained on speakers chosen for their clarity and lack of accent for kindlefags aren't going to be robust for memes. There's a hint of "I'm going to teach you how to meditate while you jog" in every inference.

I'm unironically impressed by how good tortoise does at replicating the male Imperial voice from Morrowind. The latent was built ~180 samples from Morrowind's datafiles, each 2-5 seconds in length:
using fast preset reading a copypasta (cant remember render time): https://voca.ro/130xBfm9ULiw
ultra fast preset, sneedpasta: https://voca.ro/12KaK9kDBEi2
ultra fast preset reading a book from Oblivion (took about 6 minutes to generate on a 4090 as I didn't want to wait an hour): https://vocaroo.com/14qgBk1iOjcX

Link to the latent + dataset: https://files.catbox.moe/s4il3l.zip

From what I can tell, deeper clear bass/baritone voices map better to male voices and are less likely to jump into random english girl mode. I would assume similar for higher pitched female voices. Voices that are more dynamic tend to break more.

I estimated that it would cost ~$4000 to rent enough time to train tortoise the exact same way that the dev trained his model, which is obviously not good enough.

What we need to do is replace GPT-2 in his model with a better, larger transformer model, gather a very large dataset--larger than his at 50,000 hours of English, and continue training it for an undisclosed period of time, until it begins to overfit and we can select the best model following the Chinchilla approach.

This is highly improbable to work with cash money. Likely we'd need to get hivemind working with decentralized training.
That way, the model can keep training while anons still have the willpower and bills to pay while not having to deal a questionable cash flow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91421686
The data, wherever it comes from, also needs to be preprocessed.
Tortoise is known to fuck up immensely when given non-speech sounds.
This is because the training data does not, and realistically will not contain non-speech sound effects.
The source audio has to be cut down to a certain length, containing at most multiple sentences.

Then each clip needs to be transcripted. This step is critical, because the transcription process will decide how adaptable your model is to non-speech sounds, such as laughing or SNIIFFFFing

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91442790
Secure boot in standard UEFI is really great feature, since it allows you to boot into any modern OS while allowing you to authenticate your /boot partition. Thats great, since many organisations need to use Windows or some just werks linux distro on their workstations, while also having a decent level of physical security.
>glowies probably already have their own Microsoft approved certificate for their rootkits
In 99% of the cases, glowies live rent-free in your head, but if you really think that some advanced adversaries want to go after you, get yourself a device compatible with Heads and Qubes. Preferably get a Purism device, but you should be fine with lenovo x230/T430 (assuming that you can buy those from nitrokey or flash heads yourself). In regards of UEFI, you can usually remove the preconfigured certs and add your own (but in some cases it might brick your device).
